Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Andrew Feig from Wayne State University to study a new approach to using chimeric proteins that can spontaneously transport themselves across the cellular membrane of eukaryotic cells. The chimeric proteins will be built using a scaffold based on toxins from Clostridium difficile. These toxins kill host cells by transporting a glucosyltransferase that initiates apoptosis by modifying cellular G-proteins. The Feig team works to remove the natural catalytic domain and replace it with designed cargos. This is expected to allow for the delivery of metabolically active proteins in lieu of the natural cargo domain. Chimeras are to be optimized to improve their delivery properties and test the limits to which this technology can be pushed to regulate cellular functions by direct protein delivery to cells. In addition, the possibility to replace the domain of the toxin that normally binds the cell surface with fragments that recognize specific receptors is being explored. The goal is to effectively target cargo delivery to only those cells expressing the designated partner. This would achieve a holy grail of protein delivery since it would provide tunable cell selectivity and deliver tagless proteins directly to the cytosolic compartment.

Scientists have, for many years, manipulated cells to study the way in which individual proteins contribute to cellular functions. However, a major limitation of this approach is that one is limited to those building blocks available in the cell since the proteins are still translated by the ribosome. This work will further develop technology that was recently put forth by the Feig Lab that allows properly designed proteins to transport themselves across the cell membrane releasing an active protein in the cytosol without any residual tags. There are many potential uses for such technology including the targeted delivery of protein therapeutics, the delivery of modified proteins that can be easily tracked within the cell to study their fate and the manipulation of cellular pathways. The project will be integrated with faculty development work that the principal investigator is involved with that trains new faculty in the fields of Chemistry and Biochemistry to use evidence-based teaching methods in the classroom and to better assess the quality of student learning in real-time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The scientific focus of this projet centered on the development of chimeric proteins derived from Clostridium difficile Toxins A and B designed to deliver cargo to specific eukaryotic cells in a tagless manner. The toxins carry their own translocation system, naturally delivering a glucosyltransferase protein that is kills cells. We explored two approaches to making a protein delivery system from these species. The primary approach was to remove the catalytic domain and replace it with the cargo of interest. The second approach involved inactivating the toxin with a site-directed mutation in the active site and appending the desired cargo at the N-terminus of the protein. In addition to changing the cargos, we also changed a C-terminal region that is responsible for recognizing cells and targeting them for delivery. 

Over the 4 years fo the project we encountered a number of significant hurdles. most significantly, the chimeric proteins proved difficult to express in large quantities. Part of the difficult resulted from codon utilization. The initial design was to deliver proteins that up or down regulate apoptosis due to the ease of studying their cellular effects post-delivery. These are eukaryotic proteins while the rest of the toxin is a AT-rich bacterial species that required experssion in a Gram-positive expression strain. We eventually recoded some of the shorter cargos from scratch to make them codon-optimized for Gram-positive experession, but protein yield was still limiting. 

We did explore delivery of a few of the chimeric proteins in eukaryotic cell lines. The most advanced part of the project explored delivery of our luciferase-toxin chimera to periplasts, a form of adult stem cells that have the ability to cross the blood-brain barrier (BBB). Unfortunately, loading the periplasts with luciferase toxin proved toxic to the periplasts and they could not be used for further delivery of materials across the BBB. 

On the personnel side, three graduate students were supported in part on this project. All three students completed Masters of Science Degrees in Biochemistry and are currently employed, one working at UIUC in a core laboratory, one as a visiting faculty member at Grand Valley State University and the third for a research and technolgy firm in Michigan. Several undergraduates including two women and one African American student also participated in the work.  

In terms of Broader Impact, the PI continues to oversee the Cottrell Scholars Collaborative New Facutly Workshop for Chemistry facutly. That workshop has now completed 6 years and has nearly 400 alumni in colleges and universities around the country. It recently expanded to accomodate 70 facutly per year and is still oversubscribed. The PI continues to work on projects related to dissemination and effective implemention of evidence-based instructional practices to facutly at Wayne State and across the country. The PI serves as Director of the Research Enrichment Core for the ReBUILDetroi Program, an NIH funded effort to diversity the biomedical research workforce and is deeply involved the the WSU BEST program to promote career development of PhD students for improved career outcomes across a wide range of career tragectories. The Prof. Feig also serves as PI of an NSF-IUSE institutional transformation project at Wayne State.
